svg.text: Environmental Health Research Methodology for African Urban Settings
Novel methodology bridging machine learning discoveries with epidemiological validation
Addressing environmental burden of disease in African cities through data-driven hypothesis generation

g.text: • Lundberg & Lee (2017). A unified approach to interpreting model predictions. NIPS.
• Chen & Guestrin (2016). XGBoost: A scalable tree boosting system. KDD.
1. Extract top SHAP features → Mechanistic pathway hypotheses
• Gasparrini et al. (2010). Distributed lag non-linear models. Statistics in Medicine.
• Cross-basis functions with natural cubic splines for African urban populations
AFRICAN URBAN HEALTH CONTEXT: JOHANNESBURG CASE STUDY
METHODOLOGICAL INNOVATION FOR ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH RESEARCH
• Addresses data scarcity in LMICs • Framework for other African cities
• Evidence-based policy • Advances environmental health methods
• Lundberg, S. M., & Lee, S. I. (2017). A unified approach to interpreting model predictions. NIPS, 4765-4774.
• Chen, T., & Guestrin, C. (2016). XGBoost: A scalable tree boosting system. ACM SIGKDD, 785-794.
• Gasparrini, A., et al. (2010). Distributed lag non-linear models. Statistics in Medicine, 29(21), 2224-2234.
• Watts, N., et al. (2021). The 2020 report of The Lancet Countdown on health and climate change. Lancet, 397(10269), 129-170.
• UN-Habitat. (2020). The state of African cities 2018: The geography of African investment. UN-Habitat.
• Pillay-van Wyk, V., et al. (2016). Mortality trends and differentials in South Africa from 1997 to 2012. Lancet Global Health, 4(9), e642-e653.

svg.text: Advancing Environmental Health Research Through Explainable AI
XAI-Driven Discovery Framework | African Urban Health Research
